content: everyone why lock here welcome back
today we're gonna make some industrial scatter terrain sci-fi industrial that
kind of thing easy to do fast anybody can do it going to show you a couple
tricks that can make anything look decent and we're going to talk about
basing gonna attach it all to a base it's scatter terrain we're gonna use
foam board not MDF now that's not a new concept but I contend that the warpage
factor that you avoid with MDF but you suffer with foam can be counteracted
very easily I've talked about before on the channel but it's especially
important here because we have no rigidity in this terrain the stuff
attached to it doesn't do anything to help us flatten it out so let's get to
it standard 5 millimeter foam board
available at any crafting store and most office supply stores I'm actually using
ready board which is from Dollar Tree I'm gonna cut out a shape whatever or
shape you want for the base of your scatter terrain feature you should have
a good fresh blade in your knife to prevent tearing of the foam you want
nice clean cuts especially for this next part which is to bevel the edges with
the knife extend it out a bit draw it across to slice off a nice chamfer like
this make sure you're moving the blade back or forth not just pushing at it
should feel like a pretty gentle motion now apply some white PVA glue like
Elmer's and not watered-down fairly healthy amount like you see here and I
just used my finger to spread it out nice and smooth make sure you get nice
full coverage and some cork sheeting available at any crafting store break
off some chunks and place them on there like derelict slabs of concrete stack
them up lean them stuff like that whatever you want and then construction
sand this is quick Creek construction sand has varying sized aggregate flock
the base with it about two hours later that should be bone dry apply a base
coat of dark brown I'm using burnt umber here it helps to dip the brush in water
then wring it out and then load up the paint and apply and you'll see that a
little bit of water that's left in the brush mixes with the paint at the moment
of application and it'll be much easier to soak into that sand from capital
action oh and also basecoat the cork with black while you're at it I'll give
all that time to fully dry and chair and you'll see this it's warped awful
unusable so what do we do flip it over and apply another coat of white glue on
the underside spread it out smoothly and give it a full 24 hours to dry I know
it'll seem like it's dry after only three hours but trust me let it sit for
the full 24 hours and then it'll be perfectly flat so again look at these
terribly warped they Rock when you touch them unusable here they are with the
bottom coat set out to dry for overnight and here they are afterwards look at
that miraculous no need for MDF you can get very sturdy very durable there a
flat basis with just plain old foam board and white glue now I'm going to
take a plain tan and dry brush it on the base notice that the burnt umber base
coat kind of came out splotchy the paint was too thinned out in some parts that's
fine it actually introduces some nice variation in a moment here if you're new
to this stuff dry brushing just means load paint on the brush but then
immediately work it back off on the pallet or some paper towel until there's
almost no paint left on the brush then paint the sand and you'll see that
detail catch the last remaining bits of pseudo dry paint from your brush and
look at that not professional by any means but certainly good enough for the
table top and really simple and easy to pull off for the concrete slabs gonna
use a dark grey and do an over brush so this is not a full base coat like black
was but it's also much more than a dry brush you can see how much I'm applying
here it's like 80% coverage so the black underneath is still having some impact
to create depth then with a plain grey just gonna Nick at the edges like this
optionally I didn't do this but optionally you could dry brush the whole
slab with grey and then do this edge highlight with white instead it'll pop
more but I didn't want that this is dull wreckage scattered
now collect some Griebel here I've got a hair curler an applesauce pouch cap and
some bits from a Wendy's kids meal also connects work great and so do Lego
technics series parts these are smooth plastic so take them outside and spray
primal I like Kryolan matte black that done going to use a dark gunmetal
metallic paint and again over brush these parts like 80% coverage and then a
metallic copper just kind of strike at a few spots sporadically on each part
again not professional but very easy gets the job done now take the base and
dry fit a couple of the parts choose where you want to attach them we're
gonna be using super glue so make sure that you have some raw unpainted plastic
on the underside of the part if you don't take your knife and scrape some
paint away by the way this thing here is from make your own popsicle kit makes
for a good antenna dish I recommend a gel control super glue for this I like
Loctite gorilla brand also works great so apply a thick bead of it to the areas
that will affixed to the base and here you can see I'm leaning this on concrete
slab so I'm kind of figuring out exactly where it's gonna be touching and that's
where I'm applying the glue then set the whole thing aside to dry for a few hours
I used a good amount of gel control super glue so I'm taking no risks just
gonna give it overnight to fully cure and harden and one final touch can add
some dead foliage this is a lichen or Moss from the crafting store take some
of the tan colored stuff and just hot glue some Tufts on there easy enough and
we're about to go to the table to see the final product but real quick some
reminders if you like what you're about to see please don't hesitate to hit that
like button subscribe reminders etc etc there is a link in the description below
from my Amazon storefront easy free way to support the channel if you want just

crafting goods is sponsored by Heroes hoard which has an excellent range of

DMS guild and remember $3 patrons get free copies of all my releases so as
always to provide a little extra something here's a miniature this is a
custodian warden from a unit I'm working on just to provide scale here
he's on a 40 millimeter bass so I made six pieces of scatter here of varying
size I'll get in and look at them so again pieces from like toy kits like
Lego connects that's from Wendy's kid's meal these things here these are caps
that were on poles I think - a tricycle just protective packaging that's a hair
curler 3d printers if you have failed prints or unused prints or whatever you
can bust them up attach them here they make great wreckage connects there that
year the lichen continued to get a lot of mileage out of that probably for all
my terrain to be kind of cohesive so I treat it the same they get the same
